J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> > But it's really just using summaryString as a testing utility.  I'd be
> > tempted to write this instead, which feels clearer:
> >
> > assertThat(states, summarizeTo("GREEN 0.0 GREEN 0.5 RED 1.0"))
>
> The problem with this is that you lose the context of the "states"
> object in the method "summarizeTo". Generalizing this looks bad, as it
> resorts to the kind of reflection you showed next:
>
> > Constraint summarizeTo(String summary) {
> >     return applyTo(eq(summary), callMethod("summaryString"));
> > }
>
> callMethod on which object? Bang, you're dead. :)

Not again.  :)

Just to clarify, callMethod could be written with exactly the semantics 
needed above.  I believe that your point was that clarity has been shot 
dead, since not many people want to reason about higher-order functions 
rather than string equality when doing testing.  Very true.  This is 
what I get for choosing the first example at hand.

However, thinking harder about constraints was helpful for me.  The aha 
for me is that writing a new constraint has value whenever it allows the 
framework to get its hands on a whole value that it otherwise wouldn't 
have.  This is why I actually rarely write

assertThat(x, eq("Target string"));

(I did in the first month or so after learning JMock.  Martin Fowler: 
"Often when you come across something new it can be a good idea to 
overuse it in order to find out it's [sic] boundaries.")

assertEquals("Target string", x);

means exactly the same thing, doesn't freak non-JMock maintainers, and 
produces an error string that Eclipse can parse nicely for me.

However,

assertTrue(x < 100)

is much more troublesome.  The framework never gets its hands on the 
actual value of x, so all you get is "assertion failed" (or in Ruby, 
"<false> is not <true>".  I love that.).  Instead,

assertThat(x, lessThan(100))

exposes the actual value of x to the framework, and now you get an 
informative failure message for free.  All this is to say that 
summarizeTo was a bad place to write a constraint. 

> So...
>
>      assertThat(states.summary(), eq(new Summary(0, 0.5, 1));
>
> would be my choice.

Mine is

assertThat(states.summary(), eq(new Summary("GREEN 0.0 GREEN 0.5 RED 1.0")))

    David Saff
